title: 108_hr3995
content: The Act titled "Assuring Fiscal Honesty and Accountability Act of 2004" extends the discretionary spending caps. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to adjust discretionary spending caps for 2005 and 2006. For 2005, the new budget authority is $822,903,000,000 with $902,920,000,000 in outlays. For 2006, the new budget authority is $845,042,000,000 with $894,031,000,000 in outlays. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to adjust discretionary spending caps for fiscal year 2007. The new budget authority is $870,003,000,000 with $900,651,000,000 in outlays. Section 275 of the Act is amended by striking subsection (b). SEC. 3. Extension of pay-as-you-go requirement to 2009. SEC. 4. Automatic budget enforcement for measures considered on the floor. New section added to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding budget evasion points of order. Sec. 316 prohibits any bill or resolution that would waive spending caps or alter pay-as-you-go requirements set forth in the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The House of Representatives or the Senate cannot consider any bill, resolution, amendment, motion, or conference report that affects the budget beyond the first five fiscal years covered in the current budget resolution. Additionally, the House of Representatives cannot waive the application of this rule. The House of Representatives has specific rules for points of order, including the requirement to specify precise language and the process for consideration. Points of order are debatable for 10 minutes by each Member and decided without intervening motions. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include waiver and appeal procedures in the Senate, with specific changes to subsections (c)(1) and (d)(2). The table of contents is also updated to reflect these amendments. SEC. 5 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require disclosure of interest costs for proposed measures. SEC. 6 focuses on accountability in emergency spending. The OMB Emergency Criteria defines an emergency as a situation requiring new budget authority for the prevention or response to loss of life, property, or national security threat, and must be unanticipated and sudden. The OMB Emergency Criteria defines an emergency as a situation requiring immediate action due to unforeseen and temporary needs. Guidelines for its application must be developed within five months of the enactment of the Act. The Office of Management and Budget, along with the Office, publishes guidelines in the Congressional Record for applying the definition of emergency as per the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The House of Representatives amends its rules to allow for a separate vote on emergency spending designations in committee. The Committee on Rules must report on its activities during the Congress, including a separate item on this matter. The House of Representatives amends its rules to allow for a separate vote on emergency spending designations in committee, with all waivers of points of order relating to emergency spending listed by bill number and subject matter. Committees must notify of emergency legislation and provide reasons why the budget authority meets the definition of an emergency. The House of Representatives updates rules for emergency spending designations, requiring separate votes in committee and listing waivers of points of order. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding unreported legislation and budget compliance statements. SEC. 8 amends Clause 3(d) of rule XIII of the House of Representatives' Rules, requiring a budget compliance statement from the Committee on the Budget chairman. It assesses if a bill complies with budget requirements. SEC. 9 outlines requirements for budget act waivers in the House of Representatives. The Rules of the House of Representatives are amended to require a description and justification for any resolution that waives sections of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Additionally, a separate vote is required to waive major budget act points of order in the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives amended its rules to require a description and justification for any resolution that waives sections of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. It is not allowed to consider a rule that waives a major budget act point of order, which must specify precise language to be cognizable by the Chair. Points of order under specified sections must be debated for 10 minutes by each Member initiating the point of order and by an opponent. The House of Representatives amended its rules to require a description and justification for any resolution that waives sections of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Points of order under specified sections must be debated for 10 minutes by each Member initiating the point of order and by an opponent. The disposition of the question of consideration under this subsection with respect to a bill or joint resolution shall also determine the question of consideration under this subsection with respect to an amendment made in order as original text. SEC. 10. CBO SCORING OF CONFERENCE REPORTS. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include conference reports in the budget scoring process. This change requires a determination of whether a bill, joint resolution, or conference report provides direct spending. Additionally, conference report details must be included in the joint explanatory statement of managers. The joint explanatory statement of managers must be included in conference reports for budget scoring process.
